SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I would like to associate myself with the motion moved by the Leader of Government in the Senate (Senator Button) and seconded by the Leader of the Opposition (Senator Hill). As Senator Bell said, not every senator is like Senator Wright-and I might add that this Senate is not the same place now as it was when Senator Wright was here. Soon after his retirement, he said:

SPEECH.PARA: If you only knew the spirit of apathy in the Senate 20 years ago and see the spirit today, why, the contrast is enormous.

I would suggest that if one knew the spirit in the Senate 12 years ago, and then saw the spirit today, one would also say, `Why, the contrast is enormous'. I think it is very important for us, whilst supporting this condolence motion, to reflect on where this institution is going. I was here for only two or three years before Senator Wright retired-he retired in 1978-but I recall seeing him in the old chamber. I think he sat in the middle row, sort of a centre half-back position, and, as Senator Peter Baume said, whilst he was making a speech he was often out in the centre of the aisle or over here, as Senator Baume said, picking up a legal treatise and quoting from it. It is true, as Senator Baume said, that people came into the chamber to hear his contributions to a debate. I think probably the only one who did not come into the chamber was the person sitting sharing the bench with him, because he could not get into his seat. I do not recall who that was.

TALK.START.PARA: —Neville Bonner.

—Neville was there very, very often. He did not often miss a debate. But that was when debates were debates and there would be communication across the chamber. There is not that communication now, and that is a sad reflection on this chamber. It has changed. Of course, as Senator Bell said, not every one of us senators is like Senator Wright was. He was a truly independently minded person. He said of the Senate that it should be the check on unbridled power-the unbridled power, of course, of the Executive. Why was it that he took such a leading role, as Senator Walters quite rightly said, in that 1977 referendum campaign? Because had that proposal been adopted, in his view-and it was my view, as it was of a handful of others who opposed that proposition-it would reduce the power of the Senate as a check on the unbridled power of executive government and particularly of the Prime Minister of the day.

SPEECH.PARA: Mr President, in view of the time I should like simply to associate myself with this condolence motion and convey my sympathy to the widow and family of the late Sir Reginald Wright.
Question resolved in the affirmative, honourable senators standing in their places.

DEBATE.TITLE: DEATH OF THE HON. ROBERT CUMMIN KATTER

TALK.START.PARA: —It is with deep regret that I inform the Senate of the death on 18 March 1990 of the Hon. Robert Cummin Katter, a former member of the House of Representatives for the division of Kennedy from 1966 until his retirement earlier this year.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Government in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate expresses its deep regret at the death, on Sunday, 18 March 1990, of Robert Cummin Katter, member of the House of Representatives for the seat of Kennedy from 1966 until his retirement earlier this year, places on record its appreciation of his long and meritorious public service and tenders its profound sympathy to his family in their bereavement.

Bob Katter was born on 5 September 1918 at Brisbane, Queensland. He grew up in Cloncurry, where his family ran the general store. He attended school in Charters Towers where he was an athletics and football champion and active in local theatre and public speaking. He studied law at the University of Queensland and served as an infantry captain in World War II.

Before entering Federal Parliament, Bob Katter was a councillor for the Cloncurry Shire from 1946 to 1967, including two periods as Chairman. He served as a member of the executive of the Queensland Local Government Association and was Chairman of that Association's Canberra Committee on Local Government. He was one of the Federal Parliament's longest serving National Party members. He was Minister for the Army in the McMahon Government in 1972. He served on various Commonwealth delegations and parliamentary committees, including the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Road Safety, on which he served as Chairman from 1976 to 1983; the Joint Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade; and the Joint Select Committee on the Family Law Act from 1978 to 1980.

Throughout his long public life Mr Katter represented the people of north Queensland with dedication and energy. I must say that I did not know Bob Katter well, but on at least two occasions I visited Mount Isa-I think as a Minister on each occasion. Bob Katter, as the member for that area, with the proprietorial air which National Party members for big electorates tend to have, extended considerable hospitality to me, although I suppose I was there to try to get rid of him. On each of those occasions when I was in his electorate I appreciated his kindness and hospitality to me.

There are, of course, many occasions when we express sorrow at the passing of former members. On this occasion the sadness is keen, in part because he was so recently a colleague in the House of Representatives. The memories are fresh and we think of him with respect. On behalf of the Government I extend to Mr Katter's family our sincere sympathy on their bereavement.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Opposition I join the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Button) in support of the motion and in expressing our sympathy to the family of the late Bob Katter. I will not reiterate the details of his career as they have just been outlined by the Leader of the Government, but I will repeat his record in public life-that is, 20 years as a councillor for the Cloncurry Shire and 24 years as a National Party member of this Parliament. That, in anyone's language, is an enormous contribution in public service and one for which we should all be grateful.

SPEECH.PARA: He pursued many interests in this place, some of which should be particularly remembered. Firstly, I refer to his representation of the interests of northerners. This always seemed to be his first priority. He was a co-founder of the Longreach Stockman's Hall of Fame. After the change of government in 1972 he was coalition spokesman for northern development and the Northern Territory. Secondly, he served on many committees and was particularly interested in foreign affairs and defence. You will remember, Mr President, his contribution to a document headed Threats to Australia's Security which became known as the Katter report, which was put down in 1981 by the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence. It was recommended by one reviewer as `required reading for anyone who seeks a well-informed, clearly written and bipartisan document'-and I will come back to that committee contribution in a moment.

Thirdly, I think he will be remembered for his service over 11 years on the House of Representatives Select Committee on Road Safety. He was deeply concerned about the road toll and argued strenuously for the introduction of random breath testing on a national basis.

In this strange business of politics, there are some with whom one comes into contact rarely and some whom one meets often. I actually had a lot of contact with Bob Katter over the nine years that I have been in this place through our mutual interest in foreign affairs and defence and our mutual involvement on the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence. I will remember certain aspects of his contribution. I will always remember his enthusiasm. He had great pride in Australia. He was always an optimist and, I think felt that there were too many pessimists within our community.

His pride extended particularly to his view of the Australian armed forces. When we travelled together visiting military establishments and when he saw military personnel in this place, he was constantly putting to them how important he regarded their work and their commitment. Also, I will always remember his attitude to foreign visitors, which was a lesson to us all. The Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence receives many foreign visitors. Bob Katter was always present, and was not only courteous but also genuinely warm in welcoming these visitors to our shores, and in that way- which may not be known to many senators-was, in my view, a great ambassador for Australia.
On behalf of the Opposition, I extend to his widow and children our sincere sympathy in their bereavement.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boswell Sen R.L.D.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOSWELL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —I support the motion moved by the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Button). Bob Katter was well known to many of us both in the Senate and in the House of Representatives. As Senator Button has said, he was a person who would go out and welcome people into his electorate. I well recall him on one occasion turning up to welcome the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) to his electorate at Mount Isa. When visiting Mount Isa during the last campaign, the Prime Minister offered to go and see Bob Katter in hospital.

SPEECH.PARA: Bob Katter was born in 1918 in Brisbane and grew up in north Queensland. He was the proprietor of the local drapery business, menswear store and picture theatre. He won the seat of Kennedy in 1966 and held it until six days before the election. Kennedy had been an Australian Labor Party electorate held by the Riordan family for two generations. Bob Katter won that seat because he had the ability to mix with the mighty and the humble and would give each the same time and consideration. He was just as much at home with the leader of the grazing community or the captain of the mining industry as he was with the ringers, fencers, fettlers, kangaroo shooters and the Aboriginals. In fact, he had a special affinity with the Aboriginal people and was extremely kind and generous to them.

Before television came to the bush, one of the main sources of entertainment in country Queensland was a night at the pictures, and it was customary at that time for Aboriginal people to sit on the hard benches either in the back or front of the theatre and the Europeans to sit in the canvas chairs. Bob Katter would not tolerate that segregation. In fact, he removed the hard chairs so that everyone was forced to share the canvas seats.

Those attributes were passed on to his son, young Bob. Bob junior played with the Cloncurry Tigers, which was an all-black team. The reason he played with the all-blacks is that he did not like racism or segregation. Bob Katter champ- ioned the causes of north Queensland and his beloved seat of Kennedy. In his maiden speech he called for the development of the north. He saw the tremendous job potential, the job opportunities and the wealth creation that were in north Queensland-the timber industry, cattle industry, mining, wool growing-and he continually fought for people in the bush to have the same facilities as were taken for granted in the cities. In his maiden speech he called for television for remote areas, and he lived to see three television stations servicing north Queensland, including his electorate. He successfully pushed for decent communication, and at present very few people in western Queensland do not have a telephone or some decent form of communication. That is a tribute to him. I can remember probably less than 12 months ago being at a meeting with him in the town of Blackall, where he continued to fight for people to get off party lines and to have some form of communication comparable to that of the cities. Bob always said that he thought everyone was entitled to know who won the last on Saturday.

Bob Katter worked hard for a decent road system in north Queensland. When he was elected to the House of Representatives in 1966 it was a seven-hour drive between Cloncurry and Mount Isa, a distance of some 200 kilometres. It is now a comfortable one-hour journey because he achieved decent roads for the north. Bob was an achiever for his massive electorate of Kennedy, an electorate that is three times the size of Victoria. Both he and his wife, Joy, moved around the electorate, calling on the major centres but never neglecting little towns like Dajarra, five or six houses. He kept in communication with his electorate. He was also a great supporter of the underprivileged.

Bob had a great many years in local Government, as Senator Button has said, as a councillor, deputy chairman and chairman of Cloncurry Shire Council. He was a man before his time in a lot of ways. As chairman of the Cloncurry Shire Council he was responsible for the installation of fridges and evaporative air conditioners by making bulk purchases and amortising them against the cost of the rates, because he knew that many of the people there could never afford those amenities that are so necessary in the heat and the dryness of western Queensland.

While he was its chairman the local shire council provided small one-room cottages for retired station workers who were living in absolutely appalling conditions in Cloncurry and were unable to afford any accommodation. He was well respected and admired in the local government community right throughout Queensland and was a member of the Queensland Local Government Association and an executive of the western Queensland local government association. He continued that interest right up until his demise. I can recall going out and meeting Senator Reid and a number of other senators on a local government committee when he was taking them around and showing them north Queensland only a couple of years ago. He served in the Army between 1936 and 1942, rising to the rank of captain. I can recall him naming one of the Army helicopters after the Kalkadoons, who were the local Aboriginal people in Cloncurry. Mr Bob Katter was a legend in Kennedy and a legend in north Queensland. There are many Katter stories told about Bob right throughout the north.

I believe that the people in Mount Isa said it all on the day of the funeral. Many thousands of people lined the streets from the church to the cemetery to pay their respects to their member of 24 years. He had won a great deal and done much for north Queensland. Bob lived by the maxim, `Work hard, play hard and pray hard'. He is survived by his wife Joy, four sons-Bob, Norman, Carl, Richard-and two daughters-Geraldine and Bernadette. On behalf of the National Party of Australia, I extend our sympathy to them.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacGibbon Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to add a brief personal tribute to the late Bob Katter. This afternoon the Senate is revering the passing of two really great characters of the Australian Parliament in Reg Wright and Bob Katter. They were very different people, although of somewhat similar build physically. Bob Katter was one of those really great Queensland personalities. He was known throughout the length and breadth of the State. It was my pleasure to meet him in 1977 when I was campaigning for the Senate, and he exhibited that generosity to me to which Senator Button referred. I think that in all the time I have been in the Senate Bob and I constantly shared membership on one committee or another.

SPEECH.PARA: Reference has been made to Bob Katter's great interest in defence. About six years ago I succeeded him as Deputy Chairman of the Joint Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence but, as Senator Hill has said, Bob's interest in that committee was undimmed. Bob Katter was a man of very great generosity and very great enthusiasm-enthusiasm for life in all its many facets. He was also a man of great love for his family and for the community-not any one part of it and not with any narrow vision, but for the whole country, the whole of Australia. He was a very proud Australian. In my experience around Queensland he had absolutely no enemies at all, and that is a claim that very few of us in politics can make. Bob was genuinely liked and admired by all the people who knew him. I think that great admiration for Bob was shown by the community at his funeral service in Mount Isa where, sadly, since it was only a few days before the election, a large number of his colleagues who would otherwise have been there from this Parliament were not able to attend. But from all over Queensland, and particularly from Mount Isa and the Kennedy region, they turned up in their legions to pay their last respects. It was a privilege to know Bob, and his passing is a great loss for his family, for his friends and for Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to associate the Australian Democrats with the condolence motion moved by Senator Button. I think that Senator Hill put it very well when he said that one of the characteristics that Bob Katter exhibited to overseas guests was courtesy. It was an extraordinary strong type of courtesy that he exhibited; always very robust but never abrasive. It was, to me at least, an experience to see how he handled those two sides. Unfortunately, not many of us manage to get them right.

SPEECH.PARA: I think that Bob Katter was one of the first House of Representatives people I met when I came to the Senate 10 years ago. Unfortunately, honourable senators have very little contact with honourable members of the House of Representatives, but one tends to meet one's colleagues on plane trips more than anywhere else. On many occasions going back to Queensland we drew corresponding seats. We talked about a lot of things, but I think the thing I remember most about him was his great love of his family. They were, despite his intensive public life, something that he cherished greatly. He had, of course, as all honourable senators know, a young family as well as his older children. He was always proud to talk about their school achievements. We spent a lot of time swapping stories about what our children were doing at various stages in school.

That love of children, of course, extended to his work on the Parliamentary United Nations Children's Fund committee as a member of the executive; it was not in fact simply limited to his own children. Bob Katter had a genuine human compassion for the plight of children around the world. Indeed, as I have found out over the years it is impossible to move anywhere in his electorate or to talk with any council in north-west Queensland without hearing Bob Katter stories, a lot of which are not able to be repeated here. One cannot go anywhere without hearing one of those stories, and they added up in number.

During the last election campaign, I was in the Kennedy area. People knew that Bob Katter was then sick and, later, that he had died. A lot of them talked about him and about their memories of him. The comments were all of the type that Senator MacGibbon has referred to. I never ever met anyone anywhere who had anything bad to say about him. That is, as Senator MacGibbon has said, not something that is universal in this profession. Bob Katter was well loved throughout the entire area and will be sadly missed. It is indeed disappointing that he could not have had a long retirement after his extraordinarily vigorous and lengthy public life.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bjelke-Petersen Sen F.I.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to join with the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Button), the Leader of the Opposition (Senator Hill), the National Party of Australia (Senator Boswell) and other honourable senators in paying tribute to the late Hon. Bob Katter, who for almost 25 years was a member of the Federal Parliament and who served the people of Kennedy, his electorate in north-west Queensland based on Mount Isa, faithfully and well.

SPEECH.PARA: The late Bob Katter, as has been mentioned here by quite a number of speakers, was Minister for the Army in the McMahon Government for a short period and he was a loyal and hardworking member of the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence. I believe that that was really one of the very important matters in his life as a member of parliament. He was certainly very involved in it and he regularly attended meetings. I suppose that came from the fact that he was a member of the Australian Army himself from 1936 until 1942, when he rose to the rank of captain.

I was interested in what our Leader of the Opposition said about Bob Katter's appreciation of the defence forces. That would have come, of course, as I said, from his having been in the Army. At his funeral I thought to myself how pleased Bob would have been to have known that an Army colonel and major were there representing the Governor-General and the Queensland Governor.

Prior to becoming a member of parliament, Bob had been very active in local government, having served two terms as the chairman of the Cloncurry shire and through executive positions with the Queensland local government associations.

I have been in and out of Mount Isa over many years, firstly as the wife of the Premier of Queensland and then latterly as a senator. The hospitality of the Katter home was extended to me on many occasions. Actually, I have often said that the best feed of barramundi that I have ever had was given to me by Joy Katter in the Katter home at Mount Isa. It was lovely fresh barramundi from the Gulf of Carpentaria and beautifully cooked by Joy.
I often met Bob on the plane, especially if I had seat 1A. Bob's seat was always 1B. No-one ever got seat 1B if Bob Katter was travelling on the plane.

At one time Bob represented part of South Burnett, my home district, when it was in his vast electorate of Kennedy which took in almost one-third of the State of Queensland. When I say that Queensland fits Victoria into it seven times you know just how great an area Bob had to look after. He travelled that whole area so often that it is a wonder that his children knew him, particularly the younger ones, because he was away from home so often. But that was his job and he put 100 per cent effort into it.

It is no wonder that Mount Isa paid a tremendous tribute to him on the day of his funeral. People came not only from Mount Isa, but also, as Senator MacGibbon said, from far afield to pay a tribute to Bob Katter. The church was full to overflowing and the crowds lined the streets all the way to the cemetery. The tribute that his son, Bob junior, the member for Flinders, paid to his father that day brought tears to many people's eyes; members of the Katter family took part in the service.

The late Bob Katter was an executive member of our pro-life group in the Parliament and also an attending member of our parliamentary christian fellowship. His christian faith meant a lot to him. As a Queensland senator and as a friend I want to pay this tribute to him and extend to Joy and the children at home, Carl, Richard and Bernadette, and indeed to other members of the family, young Bob, Geraldine and Norman, my sincere sympathy and pray that God will be their comfort in their loss of a devoted husband and father.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sheil Sen G.

TALK.START.PARA: —Bob Katter was known as Alligator Katter long before we ever got Crocodile Dundee and he was a very colourful denizen of the north. He drove around that gigantic electorate of Kennedy incessantly and visited every nook and cranny in it. If he did not know everybody in Kennedy, then everybody in Kennedy knew Bob. He was the consumate politician, as has been attested here. I do not want to go over all the tributes again, but I appreciate all the things that he did.

SPEECH.PARA: As was said by Senator Macklin, everybody in the north of Queensland had a story about Bob Katter, he was so well known. He did not tell any of them, but I think that a couple are worth recalling. On one occasion he was driving along one of these long outback roads when he saw a plume of dust approaching from the other direction; it was another car. As he slowed down to pass he saw the other driver had the window down. The lady who was driving put her head out to say something to him as she went past. He put his window down and his head out and she said, `Pig'. He just had time to stick his head out the window to say, `Bitch'. He went on in the dust and hit the pig!

I remember another story. After a meeting way out west a little group was having a cup of tea. All of a sudden a minibus full of Japanese spending a few days in the outback arrived. When they got out of the bus they were all chattering away and talking and laughing. Bob sent one of the chaps over to the interpreter to ask what they were all talking about. He came back laughing his head off. He said `You won't believe this. They've been on that bus on that road there for two hours and they haven't passed another car. They wanted to know if it is a one-way street'. I do not think any of them realised the vast distances we had to cover in those times.

But Bob Katter enjoyed parliamentary life. The highlight for him was when he was Minister for the Army. I think he felt he made a solid contribution there; I am sure he did. He enjoyed his time as a parliamentary representative at the United Nations which was another highlight of his career. The foundation of the Stockman's Hall of Fame gave him enormous satisfaction. The Hall of Fame is a highlight of the trip from the Great Barrier Reef to Ayers Rock in the middle of Australia. I also mention his contribution to local government which is a subject he dearly loved to deal with and spent endless time on. He also made an enormous contribution to road safety in Australia.

As has been said, he has had two families. His first wife died after a long and distressing illness. He then married Joy and they had another family, a lovely family whom he doted on. Just before he died I ran into him one day when he was going into the hospital. He knew the jig was up. He said `Oh, I just want to hang on a little. I want the grandchildren to be able to remember me'. He was a family man right to his heart.

As a matter of fact I think he would have liked to establish a dynasty in Kennedy if his son, young Bob, could have got the preselection. But, as he said, it seemed as though he had run into a great big fat bladder of lard. I do not know what that was but he had a colourful way of expressing everything. So that was one disappointment for him. But I have appreciated his career no end and I express my sympathy to Joy and the family and add what support I can to this motion of condolence.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tambling Sen G.E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a great tribute to Bob Katter that so many honourable senators can speak of him with such great personal memory and identification. For a person to contribute to public life from the levels of local government to the General Assembly of the United Nations and then also incorporate in his term so many areas and fields of community endeavour is a very great plus and positive attribute. He was man who made a marvellous contribution.

SPEECH.PARA: Bob Katter stood for election 10 times to this Federal Parliament and was successful on every occasion. Like many other members and senators I shared a great deal of interest in the area of northern Australia with the late Bob Katter. I shared a common electorate boundary both in the House of Representatives and in the Senate as a senator for the Northern Territory. I know that I am speaking for my party colleagues, Sam Calder, Bernie Kilgariff and Paul Everingham who also had a great deal to do with Bob in his parliamentary career in this particular place.

My memories of Bob Katter go back to the period shortly after my election to the Northern Territory Legislative Assembly in late 1974. That was the period of the Whitlam administration and Bob Katter at that time was the Opposition spokesman for northern development and the Northern Territory. I have two very vivid memories of Bob in that particular period. One relates to the early moves and initiations for self-government for the Northern Territory. We certainly enjoyed the major support of Bob Katter in progressing the Northern Territory's case for further transfers of power and for what finally eventuated in self-government in 1978. He must have been so proud to have been a party to that.

A month or so after I was elected, Cyclone Tracy hit Darwin. One of the first parliamentarians to visit Darwin on that occasion was Bob Katter. He was in there, I think, on the first or the second day and had a very personal and meaningful involvement in the negotiations that were so necessary with Dr Cairns and so many other people in the very early days.

I know that there are thousands of my constituents in the Northern Territory who share in the great loss of Bob's passing. As other honourable senators have mentioned, these of course include thousands of Aboriginal territorians who also knew him so well through his operation in Mount Isa. I would like to express the condolences of my party, the Northern Territory Country Liberal Party. We remember the special endeavours that Bob made on behalf of the Northern Territory and I express sympathy to Joy and the family.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brownhill Sen D.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to associate myself with the condolence motion moved by Senator Button for the Hon. Robert Katter. Ten times elected as the member for Kennedy and once to heaven, which is surely where he is now because he would be one of the people first elected to that area.

SPEECH.PARA: If ever there was a member of this Parliament who could be called `Hail Fellow, Well Met', Bob Katter was that member. He was a tireless worker for his electorate and for the people of the Australian traditional outback. He played a formidable part in the establishment of the Australian Stockmen's Hall of Fame. This man, a traditionalist for the outback, will be missed by this Parliament. We are all the poorer for his passing. I share with the family the loss they feel at this stage and extend the sympathy of all the National Party people in New South Wales to Joy and the family.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I, too, would like to join briefly in this set of tributes to Bob Katter, who I first met when I became a member of the House of Representatives halfway through his 24 years of service in that chamber. I have an immense professional and personal regard for Bob Katter-a professional regard because of the incredible example he gave to all members of Parliament, particularly in the matter of caring for his constituents. He faced 10 elections in 21 years during his 24 years of service-one almost every two years. He had three-quarters of a million square kilometres to look after. That is the size of the Kennedy electorate. The burden that imposed on him personally and physically was enormous. Yet, as other speakers have said, he was probably one of Australia's best known members of parliament so far as his constituents were concerned. Any one of us who went to his electorate was greeted, as has been said, with incredible hospitality. His achievements, culminating in his period as a Minister of the Crown, speak for themselves, but his holding for 24 years of what was traditionally a Labor seat, which on his death was regained by Labor, is a further indication of the outstanding personal contribution he made on behalf of his constituents.

SPEECH.PARA: The two people we have mourned so far today-Sir Reginald Wright and Bob Katter-both served their country in the Parliament and in the defence forces. Between them they served this Parliament for more than 50 years. They contributed immensely to our nation and we are certainly the poorer for their passing.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, Bob Katter, as has been detailed before the Senate, gave distinguished public service over a very long time. Also, he was a family man. He often spoke of his family. He had a great feel and compassion for the battlers, the under-privileged and the voiceless, including unborn human beings, expressing their rights. He was a great raconteur. Time does not permit me to tell the great story he told me the last time I met him. He was a great man and a great mate of mine. I felt his death very deeply and personally, and I would like Joy to know that prayers were offered for him as far south as Hobart. I would like to extend to her and to all of his family my deepest sympathy.

SPEECH.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative, honourable senators standing in their places.
